Award.AwardTitle: Interfacing earth-abundant electrocatalysts with mesostructured oxide photoanodes for solar photoelectrocatalysis.
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division of the National Science Foundation, Professor Daniel Gamelin at the University of Washington, Seattle, will carry out studies in the area of solar energy conversion and storage in the form of chemical fuels. Specifically, this project seeks to address the challenge of interfacing non-crystalline water-oxidation electrocatalysts with crystalline semiconductor photoelectrodes for photolectrochemical (PEC) solar energy conversion. The research will use a combination of preparative and analytical techniques to develop a deeper understanding of interfaces in a set of composite catalyst/semiconductor photoanodes. The principal investigator (PI) will apply state-of-the-art photoelectrochemical and spectroscopic techniques to assay these photoelectrodes and to advance understanding of microscopic relationships between surface morphology, functionalization, and redox catalysis. The PI and his team will seek to develop fundamental structure/function relationships that address catalyst-semiconductor coupling, electron-hole recombination dynamics, and the impact such catalysts have on the photoanode electronic structure. The research will address mechanistic differences between electrocatalytic and photoelectrocatalytic responses of this family of water-oxidation catalysts, as well as performance differences. This work will improve the solar water splitting efficiencies of these composite photoanodes in PEC cell configurations, particularly at low overpotentials where recombination losses are most severe and detrimental to energy conversion efficiencies.

This research will focus on interfacing non-crystalline Earth-abundant electrocatalysts with mesostructured oxide photoanodes for use in solar photoelectrochemical devices capable of splitting water that will generate hydrogen as a chemical fuel. This research will advance the general understanding of such composite photoelectrodes for photoelectrochemical solar energy conversion. The research will yield new complex materials and new fundamental knowledge that could broadly impact future alternative-energy technologies. This project will also provide advanced interdisciplinary training in the areas of inorganic, physical, electro-, and materials chemistries, in order to prepare participating undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral researchers for future careers in science, engineering, and education. There is a special emphasis on integration of research and education at the early career levels (undergraduate, high school) through aggressive involvement of undergraduates, incorporation of experiments and concepts from this research into the University of Washington undergraduate curriculum, collaboration with faculty and students from undergraduate institutions, and mature outreach activities at Seattle-area high schools and community colleges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A primary outcome of this work has been to substantially advance the understanding of the reaction chemistry of composite oxide/catalyst photoelectrodes used for solar water splitting. This work involved a combination of materials synthesis, spectroscopy, electrochemistry, photoelectrochemistry, and reactivity studies, and demonstrated the key roles that amorphous electrocatalysts can have in altering and improving the performance of oxide photoelectrodes in solar water oxidation catalysis. This project's research advances have helped to reconcile conflicting and contradictory literature interpretations of the effects of such catalysts by analyzing the importance of several key factors including surface structuring, catalyst thickness, and applied potential. Significant advances were made in understanding the relationship between surface recombination dynamics, hole transfer (to catalyst) dynamics, and water oxidation dynamics. Photoelectrochemical impedance spectroscopy measurements were shown to provide kinetic parameters that could predict photoelectrochemical current densities as a function of these key variables, allowing interpretation of the microscopic underpinnings of the observed phenomena. The results from this project represent significant contributions to the field of solar photoelectrochemical water splitting and are having broad impact by drawing attention to apparent inconsistencies in the field's understanding, and then reconciling these inconsistencies within a universal model. This project has also made important fundamental advances in the understanding of visible-light-absorbing oxides that are future potential photoelectrode materials. Detailed characterization of Fe2O3/Cr2O3 heterostructures and superlattices has shed light on the possibility of using internal bias to enhance charge separation in such materials, and has demonstrated this effect experimentally using photoconductivity probes of free charge-carrier photogeneration. Additionally, analysis of phase stability in novel visible-light-absorbing metastable materials (w-Zn1-xCoxO) has helped to understand the experimentally accessible composition ranges where this material may be useful as a photoelectrode material.

 

Each participating undergraduate and graduate student has received advanced training in the complementary areas of inorganic chemistry, physical chemistry, electrochemistry, spectroscopy, surface science, materials science, and nanotechnology. Each participant has worked as part of an integrated collaborative team. This broad training experience has prepared these participants well for future challenges in academia and industry. Senior graduate students were also each involved in the mentoring other undergraduate and graduate students, in leadership of joint group meetings, and in responsibility for major instrumentation. These activities have provided invaluable training and contributed to a well-balanced educational experience. Each of these participants (except those still in the program) has successfully gone on to earn a STEM degree, and for graduate students, to industrial or postdoctoral employment. In the course of this project, the PI has worked to integrate research findings from this project into his teaching and outreach activities, and to engage the broader community in related energy and materials science education. The PI and his group have been active in the outreach efforts of UW's (state-funded) Clean Energy Institute and UW's NSF Center for Enabling New Technologies for Catalysis (CENTC). Project participants together with a team of UW graduate students, postdocs, and staff, have designed a multi-day high school outreach program based on alternative fuels and the synthesis of biodiesel, involving presentations, discussions, demonstrations, and hands-on laboratory experiences. In the past two academic years, over 20 classes were visited at 3 different Seattle high schools, reaching over 800 students. Participants also helped to staff a hands-on science display booth at community events held in conjunction with the Pacific Science Center. These activities engage regional high-school students and members of the broader public in discussions about energy and science, stimulating them to consider new ideas for solving current or future technological challenges.

 


Last Modified: 05/03/2017
Modified by: Daniel R Gamelin
